monster.name: Nabassu (Progeny of Solqommon)

trait.name: Demonic Shadows
entries: The nabassu darkens the area around its body in a 10-foot radius. Nonmagical light can't illuminate this area of dim light.

trait.name: Devour Soul
entries: A nabassu can eat the soul of a creature it has killed within the last hour, provided that creature is neither a construct nor an undead. The devouring requires the nabassu to be within 5 feet of the corpse for at least 10 minutes, after which it gains a number of Hit Dice ({@dice d8}s) equal to half the creature's number of Hit Dice. Roll those dice, and increase the nabassu's hit points by the numbers rolled. For every 4 Hit Dice the nabassu gains in this way, its attacks deal an extra 3 ({@dice 1d6}) damage on a hit. The nabassu retains these benefits for 6 days. A creature devoured by a nabassu can be restored to life only by a {@spell wish} spell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The nabassu has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The nabassu's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The nabassu uses its Soul-Stealing Gaze and makes two attacks: one with its claws and one with its bite.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one willing creature, or a creature that is {@condition grappled} by the vampire, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition restrained}. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d12 + 6}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the vampire regains hit points equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. A humanoid slain in this way and then buried in the ground rises the following night as a vampire spawn under the vampire's control.

action.name: Soul-Stealing Gaze
entries: The nabassu targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the nabassu and isn't a construct or an undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Charisma saving throw or reduce its hit point maximum by 13 ({@damage 2d12}) damage and give the nabassu an equal number of temporary hit points. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest. The target dies if its hit point maximum is reduced to 0, and if the target is a humanoid, it immediately rises as a ghoul under the nabassu's control.

legendaryHeader: The nabassu can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The nabassu regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The nabassu moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: The nabassu makes one unarmed strike.

legendary.name: Bite (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The nabassu makes one bite attack.

entries.name: Nabassu
entries: The insatiable nabassus prowl the multiverse in search of souls to devour. If they think they can kill a creature and consume its soul, they attack—even if that other creature is a demon, including another nabassu.

entries.name: Hated Outcasts
entries: Demons have few rules, and the murder of other demons hardly raises an eyebrow among these fiends. The act of devouring souls is something else. For this reason, most demons shun nabassus and force them to live on the fringes of the Abyss. There, nabassus pick off weaker demons or, if the situation warrants, gather in packs to take down larger prey. Some especially powerful nabassus even search for demon lords' amulets.

entries.name: Demonic Infiltrators
entries: Whenever magic pulls demons from the Abyss to the Material Plane, nabassus try to get summoned so that they can embark on a feast of souls there. If a nabassu is summoned, it tries to break free so that it can devour the soul of its summoner and then set out to feed on the souls of whatever creatures it can catch. One way a summoner can avoid this fate is by providing a steady supply of souls to the nabassu, which can cause the demon to be cooperative—for as long as the supply lasts.

trait.name: Voice of Authority
entries: If you cast a spell with a spell slot of 1st level or higher and target an ally with the spell, that ally can use their reaction immediately after the spell to make one weapon attack against a creature of your choice that you can see.
If the spell targets more than one ally, you choose the ally who can make the attack.

trait.name: Embodiment of the Law
entries: If you cast a spell of the enchantment school using a spell slot of 1st level or higher, you can change the spell's casting time to 1 bonus action for this casting, provided the spell's casting time is normally 1 action.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Healing Word + Voice of Authority
entries: If you cast a spell with a spell slot of 1st level or higher and target an ally with the spell, that ally can use their reaction immediately after the spell to make one weapon attack against a creature of your choice that you can see.

action.name: Spell + Voice of Authority
entries: If you cast a spell with a spell slot of 1st level or higher and target an ally with the spell, that ally can use their reaction immediately after the spell to make one weapon attack against a creature of your choice that you can see.

bonus.name: Embodiment of the Law
entries: 1 Enchantment Spell

If you cast a spell of the enchantment school using a spell slot of 1st level or higher, you can change the spell's casting time to 1 bonus action for this casting, provided the spell's casting time is normally 1 action.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

Priests bring the teachings of their gods to the common folk. They are the spiritual leaders of temples and shrines and often hold positions of influence in their communities. Evil priests might work openly under a tyrant, or they might be the leaders of religious sects hidden in the shadows of good society, overseeing depraved rites. A priest typically has one or more acolytes to help with religious ceremonies and other sacred duties.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: Kaballus can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: Kaballus has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Kaballus makes two attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

variantrule.name: Starting Party Wealth; Wealth per Level
entries: Use the following tables to determine parties wealth at the beginning of a new campaign. Parties will start with the appropriate magic items and a sum of money, following by the tables below:

entries.name: Wealth per Level
entries: Alternatively, use the following table as a reference for the starting wealth of the party at each specific level.

variantrule.name: Magic Item Price
entries: A Minor Tier magic item's asking price is usually in the lower range of its rarity, a Major Tier is in the upper range. Use the following table as a reference.

variantrule.name: Scroll Prices; Scribing Scrolls Cost
entries: Use the following table to determine the asking price and scribing cost for spell scrolls.

default: (a) a {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon} and a {@item shield|phb} or (b) any two {@filter simple weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@light crossbow|phb} and 20 {@item arrows|phb} or (b) 5 {@item javelins|phb}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: Tinkerer
entries: A tiefling rummages through a sack hanging on his belt and ties together a pair of burnt sticks with a silk thread while mumbling half-forgotten words under his breath. With a flick of his wrist and a whistle between his lips, the tip of the jury-rigged apparatus lights up with a dim flame, ready for use.

A dwarf sits cross-legged in front of a paneled wall, tools in hand humming a tune. There is a click, a knock, a rumble. A small hole opens in the wall and a poison-tipped needle falls from the hole, harmless. She exclaims her success with a cry for joy.

A tabaxi parades through the tournament, with armor painted all colours of the rainbow and a mismatch of weapons on his back. In one fight he duels with grace and wit, rapier in hand; in another he swings a heavy maul with the ferocity of a barbarian. In the last match he wrestles a half-ogre to the ground with his bare hands. When the crowd sings a confused cheer, he flourishes with a bow.

entries.name: Skill Monkey
entries: You are a practitioner of many arts; a polymath. While some people focus on their martial skills or magical learnings, you cast a wide net. Some may argue that a wide array of skills narrows your focus, you argue that having every tool available is better than having one.

Tinkerers are people that have learned as many skills and abilities as they possibly can, and journey into the unknown to widen that array of knowledge they build. Most Tinkerers are capable of spellcasting due to the spread of their skills but they supplement this with the ability to create and find magical trinkets that replicate magic for ease of access.

entries.name: A Moment of Inspiration
entries: Tinkerer have a core set of abilities they rely on but can focus in some things they've memorized in order to fulfill a specific task. Some Tinkerers core abilities may lay in martial combat but in moments of inspiration, they may manifest the ability to read ancient languages or pick locks by scouring through their memories in an instant.

entries.name: Creating a Tinkerer
entries: As you build your Tinkerer, think about how they gained all their skills. Did they simply have no focus and learned a variety of skills, or are they are savant and wanted to broaden their horizons as widely as possible.
Think about how and where they learned different skills and who taught them what they know. Are they self-taught?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Tinkerer quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score. Your next highest should be Intelligence, and then Constitution. Second, pick the criminal or urchin background.

classFeature.name: Training Reminiscence
entries: The Tinkerer is a dabbler, a professional explorer who plunders a wide variety of fields to find the tools they need to survive. They read through tomes of arcane magic to gain a basic understanding of spells. They offer prayers to a variety of deities to gain their blessings. They observe warrior stances and exercises to understand the art of fighting. But while a Tinkerer learns many paths, they master none of them. Rather than train in a given field, they master all the basics and manages to pull out something useful when the situation is desperate enough.

To represent this seemingly random body of knowledge, a Tinkerer gains Reminiscence Points that they can expend to activate their abilities. You have a number of Reminiscence Points shown on the Tinkerer class table to expend. This pool of points refills when you finish long rest.
At certain levels, a Tinkerer gains new {@filter Tinkerer Trainings|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=TT}

classFeature.name: Field of Specialisation
entries: ---Specialisation fluff---

classFeature.name: Arcane Dilettante
entries: You acquire a vague understanding of magic. You know that with a few weird hand gestures and an array of grunts and bizarre words, you can conjure up something that looks like a spell.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: Your understanding of magic is tenuous at best. You probably didn't study at an arcane academy or tutor under an archmage. Instead, you watched wizards and sorcerers at work and learned how to mimic what they did.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Tinkerer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter tinkerer spells|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;bard} of 1st through 5th level. The table also shows what the level of those slots is; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your Tinkerer spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest.
For example, when you are 5th level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell witch bolt, you must expend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: You prepare the list of tinkerer spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the {@filter wizard or bard spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;bard}. When you do so, choose a number of tinkerer spells equal to your Intelligence modifier + half your tinkerer level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of tinkerer spells requires time spent tinkering with your spellcasting focuses: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Tinkerer spell, since you need to observe and accurately mimic other spellcasters in order to understand what, exactly, they are doing with their hands and mouth.

You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a Tinkerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: Choose two of your skill or tool proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses the chosen proficiency.

classFeature.name: Specialisation Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature granted by your Field of Specialisation.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Specialisation Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Field of Specialisation.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mind Restoring
entries: When you reach 10th level, you acquire some techniques that help you restore your focus. When you finish a short rest, you regenerate a number of Reminiscence Points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Specialisation Feature
entries: At 11th level, you gain a feature granted by your Field of Specialisation.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 14th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Specialisation Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted by your Field of Specialisation.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Specialisation Feature
entries: At 18h level, you gain a feature granted by your Field of Specialisation.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Borrowed Experience
entries: You learn to make the most of every experience you had, recollecting the details of any actions and technique you witnessed in the past. At the end of each long rest, choose three class abilities (they don't need to be from the same class). Each ability must be available to a character of that class at 18th level or lower.
As an action, you gain the benefits and drawbacks of one of the chosen abilities for 1 minute. You can't gain the Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature using the ability.
Once you use this feature on an ability, you can't use it again with that same ability until you finish a long rest.

If a feature you select has a point cost requirement, such as a {@class Monk}'s {@subclassFeature quivering palm|monk||open hand||17} ability, you must expend Reminiscence Points equal to the feature's normal point cost to activate it.

subclassFeature.name: Scholar of the Occult
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the following privileges:

items: Proficiency in one skill of your choice between: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Religion}
You learn 2 cantrips from the {@filter Wizard or Bard spell list|spells|level=0;1|class=bard;wizard}. You learn an additional one at 10th level.

You can expend Reminiscence Points to cast spells. To do so, you must expend an amount of Reminiscence Points equal to the level of the spells you intend to cast. You can only cast spells you have prepared, and still have to provide all the required components. You can cast spells at higher level this way, but you cannot exceed your maximum spell level.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Trinketry
entries: You have begun to develop your skills into temporary magical items. You don't possess the knowledge or patience required for artificing, but you have the skill for it. During a short rest, you can cobble together a trinket that can replicate cantrips.
You can have one magical trinket at a time. Making a new one causes the previous one to fall apart.

Choose one {@filter cantrip|spells|level=0} whose casting you have witnessed. You can extrapolate the casting mechanics for that cantrip into an item such as a ring, wand, or rod. This item you make contains that cantrip and Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for that cantrip. If a creature other than you tries to cast the cantrip, the item falls apart.

subclassFeature.name: Improvised Attunement
entries: You can {@book attune|DMG|7|Attunement} to magical items even if you don't meet the prerequisites for attuning to the item.

subclassFeature.name: Borrowed Attunement
entries: You can use the properties of a magical item you touch without having to attune to it by expending 1 Epiphany point as an action.

If the property is passive, such as the magical qualities of {@item Gauntlets of Ogre Power}, you gain the benefits of the item for 1 minute. If the item has an activated ability that requires charges, such as a {@item Wand of Magic Missiles}, you can use that ability at its lowest power as an action on each of your turns for 1 minute by expending Epiphany Points equal to the charge cost.
If the item is being worn or carried by an unwilling creature, you must make a melee spell attack to gain its benefits. You can only borrow the attunement of 1 item at a time.
Each magic item can be targeted by this effect once per short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Magical Trinketry
entries: You can now make trinkets containing {@filter 1st-level|spells|level=1} and  {@filter 2st-level|spells|level=2} spells from any class's spell list at the end of each long rest. You can have up to 2 Improved Magical Trinkets active at a time (in addition to your regular magical trinket). Each Improved Magical Trinket can be tapped to cast a spell a number of times equal to your Intelligence Modifier each long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Copycast Trinket
entries: You can make a Copycast Trinket at the end of a long rest. When a creature you can see within 120 feet of you casts a spell, you can expend 4 Epiphany points as a reaction to replicate the spell and cast it as part of the same reaction. The spell doesn't need to be on your spell list or of a level you can prepare, but you still have to provide the appropriate components
Once you use the Copycast Trinket to replicate and cast a spell, it breaks.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Agility
entries: Your armor class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier when you are not wearing any armor. You can don a shield and still gain the benefit from this Training.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Breach
entries: Your broad knowledge allows you to study an opponent and gain a brief flash of insight to breach their defenses. By spending 2 Epiphany points as a part of your attack, you can ignore one damage resistance of your choice of a creature you can see until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Defense
entries: You can study your opponents and learn to anticipate their attacks. When a creature you can see attacks you, you can spend 1 Epiphany point as a reaction to gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Intelligence modifier until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Dodge
entries: Your luck, reflexes, and intuition allow you to avoid an attack or spel. When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can spend 2 Epiphany Points as a reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.
You almost dodge out of the way, take cover from a spell, or otherwise escape the brunt of the damage.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Escape
entries: You can expend a Reminiscence Point to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action as a bonus action on each of your turns.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Trickster
entries: You learn 2 cantrips from any spell list. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these cantrips

optionalfeature.name: Expert Strike
entries: With a quick study of a vulnerable opponent's defenses, you can spot the precise area you need to hit to score a telling blow. You can spend 1 Resilience point to gain 1d6 points of sneak attack damage. You must follow the normal rules of sneak attack from the Rogue class. You can spend this point before or after you roll, but before results are determined.
The damage for this feature improves at certain levels (2d6 at 7th level, 3d6 at 11th level, 4d6 at 15th level, and 5d6 at 19th level).

optionalfeature.name: Expert Surge
entries: You learn how to push yourself beyond your limits when needed. By spending 3 Resilience points, you gain an extra action on top of your normal action and possible bonus action.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long or short rest.

optionalfeature.name: Expert Resilience
entries: If you take damage that would reduce you to 0 hit points, you can instead spend 4 Resilience points as a reaction to drop to 1 hit point instead.
You almost dodge out of the way, take cover from a spell, or otherwise escape the brunt of the damage.

optionalfeature.name: Clerical Training
entries: Tinkerers are legendary for the number of holy symbols, lucky trinkets, and blessed items they keep handy. As the saying goes, there are no atheists in the dungeon.

You have a pool of healing power that replenishes when you take a long rest. With that pool, as an action, you can restore a total number of hit points equal to your Factotum level × 3. Alternatively, you can expend 5 health points from your pool to cure your target from a disease of from poison. Additionally:

You prepare the list of tinkerer spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the {@filter wizard or bard spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;bard}. When you do so, choose a number of tinkerer spells equal to your Intelligence modifier + half your tinkerer level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.
If you use this ability to injure undead, you must hit with a melee spell attack. If you hit, you deal radiant damage equal to twice your factotum level + your Intelligence modifier.
If you use this ability to turn undead, you act as a cleric of a level equal to your factotum level. The saving throw for this effect uses your Spellcasting save DC.

optionalfeature.name: Quick Fencer
entries: When you take the Attack action on your turn, you can make two attacks, instead of one.

optionalfeature.name: Eldritch Connoisseur
entries: You gain the benefits of the {@feat Eldritch Adept|TCE} feat.

optionalfeature.name: Metamagic Connoisseur
entries: You gain the benefits of the {@feat Eldritch Adept|TCE} feat.

optionalfeature.name: Smart Trinket
entries: You can add your Intelligence modifier to the damage rolls of the spells stored in your magical trinkets.

optionalfeature.name: Witchcraft Initiate
entries: Every time you finish a long rest, you may choose one 2nd level ability from any Wizard subclass of which you have a spell prepared. You gain that ability for the next 24 hours, or until you select a new ability using this Training.

item.name: Eregast's Lantern
entries: This rusty lantern was created by Eregast, to be buried in his Mausoleum, deep in the jungles of Xen’Drik, after his death. The lantern appears dim and opaque, and looking inside it’s hard to tell if it’s even lit.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While holding Eregast’s Lantern with one hand, or keeping it secured to your belt, or to a rod or staff you’re holding, you gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls.
The lantern has 3 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cause one of the following effects:

items: You cast one of your artificer spells with a casting time of 1 action or less with a +1 bonus to its DC (1 charge). You still expend the corresponding spell slot normally.

You imbue the lantern with one of your artificer infusions. This doesn’t count against your maximum number of infusions, but follows the normal rules for infusing an item otherwise (3 charges). The lantern doesn’t recover these charges until you end the infusion.

entries: The lantern regains 1d2 + 1 expended charges daily at dawn.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When Eregast’s Lantern reaches an awakened state, it gains the following properties:

items: The lantern’s charges increase to 6 and it regains 1d4 + 2 expended charges daily at dawn.
The bonus to spell attack rolls increases to +2.

entries: By expending its charges you can cause the following additional effects:

items: You cast one of your artificer spells with a casting time of 1 action or less with a +2 bonus to its DC (2 charges). You still expend the corresponding spell slot normally.
You recover one or more spell slots of a total level equal to the charges you expend (es.: 3 charges for  1 level 1 and 1 level 2 slots), to a maximum of 3 between two long rests.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When Eregast’s Lantern  reaches an exalted state, it gains the following properties:

items: The lantern’s charges increase to 10 and it regains 1d6 + 4 expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the last charge, once before the next dawn, roll a d20. On a 20, the lantern regains 1d2 + 1 charges.
The bonus to spell attack rolls increases to +3.
The lantern counts as two magic items with regard to the number of magic items you can attune to.

entries: By expending its charges you can cause the following additional effects:

items: You cast one of your artificer spells with a casting time of 1 action or less with a +3 bonus to its DC (3 charges). You still expend the corresponding spell slot normally.
You recover one or more spell slots of a total level equal to the charges you expend (es.: 3 charges for  1 level 1 and 1 level 2 slots), to a maximum of 5 between two long rests.

item.name: Larhut's Hat
entries: As a bonus action, you can direct this hat to fly on another creature's head. The other creature makes a DC 20 Saving Throw. If it fails, this has the same effect as casting {@spell hold person} on that creature. The DC for the saving throw is 20

item.name: Larhut's Glasses
entries: As an action, you can activate the glasses to cast {@spell true seeing}. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

item.name: Shield (worn)
entries: A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

item.name: Shield (held)
entries: A held shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 1. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.
Donning and doffing a held shield requires an interaction.

item.name: Shield (buckler)
entries: A buckler is made from wood or metal and is worn on the forearm. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.
While wearing a buckler, you can:

items: Use a bonus action to gain a +1 bonus to your AC (this counts as a shield) until the beginning of your next turn
Use a reaction to gain a +1 bonus to your AC (this counts as a shield) on one attack

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A {@item Map or Scroll Case|phb|wooden case} containing a map to a ruin or dungeon, a {@item bullseye lantern|phb}, a {@item miner's pick|phb}, a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, a {@item shovel|phb}, a {@item two-person tent|phb}, a {@item trinket|phb|trinket} recovered from a dig site, and a {@item pouch|phb} containing 25 gp

entries.name: Description
entries: A rogue archaeologist preys on the long-lost and fallen cultures of the past by stealing and collecting their remains — their bones, their ruins, their surviving masterworks, and their tombs. Those who practice archaeology travel to the far corners of the world to root through crumbled cities and lost dungeons, digging in search of artifacts that might tell the stories of monarchs and high priests, wars and cataclysms - and fetch a high price on the black market -, often finding themselves in direct confrontation with ancient and powerful guardians and forgotten creatures.

entries.name: Dust Digger
entries: Prior to becoming an adventurer, you spent most of your young life crawling around in the dust, pilfering relics of questionable value from crypts and ruins. Though you managed to sell a few of your discoveries and earn enough coin to buy proper adventuring gear, you have held onto an item that has great emotional value to you. Roll on the Signature Item table to see what you have, or choose an item from the table.

entries.name: Feature: Historical Knowledge
entries: When you enter a ruin or dungeon, you can correctly ascertain its original purpose and determine its builders, whether those were dwarves, elves, humans, yuan-ti, or some other known race. In addition, you can determine the monetary value of art objects more than a century old.
